Module com.example.battleship
Package com.example.battleship.Model.Player

Class PlayerData

java.lang.Object
com.example.battleship.Model.Player.PlayerData
public class PlayerData extends Object
Represents player statistics and data persistence for the Battleship game.

This class stores individual player performance metrics including games played, games won, total shots fired, and accuracy. It provides CSV serialization for file-based persistence and static methods for managing multiple player profiles.

Player data is automatically stored in the data/players.csv file, with one player record per line. The class uses case-insensitive player names as unique identifiers.

      public String toCSV()
      Converts player data to CSV format.
      Returns:
      comma-separated string: "name,gamesPlayed,gamesWon,totalShots,totalHits"

      Creates a PlayerData object from CSV array.
      Parameters:
      data - string array with 5 elements: [name, gamesPlayed, gamesWon, totalShots, totalHits]
      Returns:
      PlayerData object, or null if data is invalid

      Returns:

    • savePlayerData

      public static void savePlayerData(PlayerData player)
      Saves or updates a player's data to the CSV file.

      If a player with the same name (case-insensitive) already exists, their data is updated. Otherwise, a new entry is created.

      Parameters:
      player - the PlayerData object to save

    • loadPlayerData

      public static PlayerData loadPlayerData(String playerName)
      Loads a specific player's data from the CSV file.
      Parameters:
      playerName - the player's username (case-insensitive)
      Returns:
      PlayerData object if found, null otherwise

    • loadAllPlayers

      public static Map<String,PlayerData> loadAllPlayers()
      Loads all player data from the CSV file.
      Returns:
      map of player names (lowercase) to PlayerData objects

    • getTopPlayers

      public static List<PlayerData> getTopPlayers(int limit)
      Returns the top players sorted by wins and accuracy.

      Players are first sorted by number of wins (descending), then by accuracy percentage (descending) as a tiebreaker.

      Parameters:
      limit - maximum number of players to return
      Returns:
      list of top players, may be smaller than limit if fewer players exist

    • playerExists

      public static boolean playerExists(String playerName)
      Checks if a player exists in the database.
      Parameters:
      playerName - the player's username (case-insensitive)
      Returns:
      true if player exists, false otherwise

    • deletePlayerData

      public static void deletePlayerData(String playerName)
      Deletes a player's data from the CSV file.
      Parameters:
      playerName - the player's username (case-insensitive)
